metadata.titleEn: HiWATER: Multi-scale observation eXperiment on evapotranspiration over heterogeneous land surfaces (MUSOEXE-12)-dataset of flux observation matrix (No.3 eddy covariance system) (2012)
metadata.description:
This dataset contains the flux measurements from site No.3 eddy covariance system (EC) in the flux observation matrix from 3 June to 18 September, 2012. The site (100.37634° E, 38.89053° N) was located in a cropland (maize surface) in Yingke irrigation district, which is near Zhangye, Gansu Province. The elevation is 1543.05 m. The EC was installed at 3.8 m high, and sampled at 10 Hz. The EC was installed at a height of 3.8 m; the sampling rate was 10 Hz. The sonic anemometer faced north, and the separation distance between the sonic anemometer and the CO2/H2O gas analyzer (Gill&Li7500A) was 0.2 m.
Raw data acquired at 10 Hz were processed using the Eddypro post-processing software (Li-Cor Company, http://www.licor.com/env/products/ eddy_covariance/software.html), including spike detection, lag correction of H2O/CO2 relative to the vertical wind component, sonic virtual temperature correction, angle of attack correction, coordinate rotation (2-D rotation), corrections for density fluctuation (Webb-Pearman-Leuning correction), and frequency response correction. The EC data were subsequently averaged over 30 min periods. Moreover, the observation data quality was divided into three classes according to the quality assessment method of stationarity (Δst) and the integral turbulent characteristics test (ITC), which was proposed by Foken and Wichura [1996]: class 1 (level 0: Δst<30 and ITC<30), class 2 (level 1: Δst<100 and ITC<100), and class 3 (level 2: Δst>100 and ITC>100), representing high-, medium-, and low-quality data, respectively. In addition to the above processing steps, the half-hourly flux data were screened in a four-step procedure: (1) data from periods of sensor malfunction were rejected; (2) data before or after 1 h of precipitation were rejected; (3) incomplete 30 min data were rejected when the missing data constituted more than 3% of the 30 min raw record; and (4) data were rejected at night when the friction velocity (u*) was less than 0.1 m/s. There were 48 records per day; the missing data were replaced with -6999. Moreover, suspicious data were marked in red.
The released data contained the following variables: data/time, wind direction (Wdir, °), wind speed (Wnd, m/s), the standard deviation of the lateral wind (Std_Uy, m/s), virtual temperature (Tv, ℃), H2O mass density (H2O, g/m^3), CO2 mass density (CO2, mg/m^3), friction velocity (ustar, m/s), stability (z/L), sensible heat flux (Hs, W/m^2), latent heat flux (LE, W/m^2), carbon dioxide flux (Fc, mg/ (m^2s)), quality assessment of the sensible heat flux (QA_Hs), quality assessment of the latent heat flux (QA_LE), and quality assessment of the carbon flux (QA_Fc). In this dataset, the time of 0:30 corresponds to the average data for the period between 0:00 and 0:30; the data were stored in *.xlsx format.
For more information, please refer to Liu et al. (2016) (for multi-scale observation experiment or sites information), Xu et al. (2013) (for data processing) in the Citation section.

background: The two-source energy balance (TSEB) model was successfully applied to estimate evaporation (E), transpiration (T), and evapotranspiration (ET) for land covered with vegetation, which has significantly important applications for the terrestrial water cycle and water resource management. One-source evapotranspiration estimation models combine the soil–vegetation components into a single source. However, in real landscape conditions, the surface is heterogeneous and contains a mixture of soil and vegetation having different temperatures and resistance to energy exchange. Therefore, one-source models explicitly cannot estimate the surface evapotranspiration accurately because the effect of.

Shuttleworth and Wallace proposed a typical two-source evapotranspiration estimation model in which the energy partition is assumed to occur in both “the above canopy” and “the under soil” cases. Water vapor and heat meet over the reference height in the interior of the canopy. Moreover, the mixed water vapor and heat can only exit through the top of the canopy; the total heat flux is in addition to the fluxes coming from every surface layer. However, the model is complex, having over five resistances that cannot be accurately calculated. In addition, the model includes required parameters and observations that cannot be readily obtained from operational satellite- and ground-based data; therefore, the range of applications of the model is limited.

The TSEB model has undergone several revisions, improving the estimation of soil and canopy net radiation, the aerodynamic resistance of the soil surface, the fractional vegetation coverage observed at the radiometer view angle, the distribution of regional-scale near-surface air temperature, and soil and canopy component temperatures. Because the TSEB model only requires the surface energy balance model with a single measurement of land surface temperature, the original model and subsequent refinements have been widely used to estimate E and T under a wide variety of vegetation types, vegetation coverage, climates, and spatial scales. However, most studies have only evaluated the total fluxes or ET (soil plus canopy) in comparison with measurements using the Bowen ratio–energy balance system, the eddy covariance (EC) system, or the large aperture scintillometer.

Accurately estimating surface fluxes in a strongly advective irrigated agricultural area is a particularly challenging task and is even more difficult when the EC flux measurements of H and LE have an incomplete energy balance closure with respect to the available energy Rn−G0. The previous sensitivity studies found that the TSEB model performance is mainly affected by the uncertainty in surface–air temperature difference. Sometimes, this difference is dominant due to the errors in determining the surface soil and vegetation component temperatures from the surface composite radiometric temperature. In this letter, it is shown that there is an overestimation of the component temperatures compared with the observed composite radiometric. This often leads to the most crucial effect on the TSEB model performance. In addition, another factor is the strong advective environment in this region.
research objective: In this letter, the ground-measured soil and canopy component temperatures were used to estimate E, T, and ET, which were better validated with observed ratios of E (E/ET%) and T (T/ET%) using the stable oxygen and hydrogen isotopes, and the ET measurements using an eddy covariance (EC) system.

The objective of this letter is to estimate E, T, and ET using the soil and canopy component temperatures observed via a high-resolution thermal camera as inputs to a series TSEB model and to subsequently better validate E, T, and ET using a combination of the stable oxygen and hydrogen isotope technique and EC measurements.
challenges: However, the current composite temperature separation approaches are limited in their effectiveness in arid regions. Moreover, E and T are difficult to measure on the ground.

Errors in the derived component temperature were primarily caused by image classification errors; these classification errors varied with vegetation abundance. The higher uncertainty of H estimation is not only caused by the uncertainty of the TSEB model but also due to the increased uncertainty of the EC system, which is 18% when the mean H is small in the irrigated farmland. Due to image pixel classification errors, soil pixels were counted as vegetation pixels, which produced an overestimation of the canopy temperature under the developing vegetation abundance. Alternatively, ignoring atmospheric upwelling radiation and transmittance could have produced the uncertainties in the estimated temperatures. In addition, the estimated uncertainty of the incoming short- and long-wave radiation transmittances through the canopy may be another source of Rn estimation errors.
methods: In this letter, the field observations were obtained from the Daman superstation installed in the central oasis, which is a 40-m boundary layer tower located at 100.3722° E, 38.8555° N and at an elevation of 1556 m. The meteorological parameters were measured every 10 min and included air temperature, wind speed, humidity at 5 m over the ground, four-component radiations (measured at 12 m above the ground using a four-component radiometer), and turbulent fluxes (measured at 4.5 m above the ground using an EC system with a sampling frequency of 10 Hz). The soil heat fluxes were measured using three heat plates located 6 cm under the ground. A Fluke Ti55 thermal infrared camera was manually operated on a 25-m-high platform on a boundary layer tower to measure the thermal radiation of the cropland approximately every 120 min; the observations were collected as thermal images from approximately 07:00 to 19:00 China Standard Time (CST) during the daytime. The ground-based measurement data were applied to partition ET into E and T applying the Craig–Gordon model.

To evaluate the TSEB model accurately, the soil heat flux was using the ground measurement. In addition, the soil and canopy sensible heat fluxes were estimated using the series TSEB model, and their latent heat fluxes were calculated while solving the energy balance equations (1) and (2), respectively. The soil and canopy component temperatures were calculated using the images obtained with the thermal camera. To calculate the component temperatures, the visible and NIR images were classified into soil and canopy pixels using the maximum-likelihood method. Next, the soil and canopy directional brightness temperatures were exacted from the thermal images. Finally, the thermal infrared temperatures were converted to the radiation temperatures using the incoming long-wave radiation from the sky and the soil and canopy emissivities. Next, the simulated radiometric temperatures were validated against the surface radiometric temperatures, which were calculated according to the incoming long-wave radiation observed by the four-component radiometer.
dataset: The experimental area is an artificial oasis that is covered with maize, vegetables, and orchards. Data of day of year (DOY) 170, 173, 176, 192, 195, 231, 252, and 256 were used to determine ET and the ratios of E (E/ET%) and T (T/ET%) to ET during the Multi-Scale Observation Experiment on Evapotranspiration over heterogeneous land surfaces, which was part of the Heihe Water Allied Telemetry Experimental Research (HiWATER-MUSOEXE).
findings: Our results indicated that even under the strongly advective conditions, the TSEB model produced reliable estimates of the E/ET% and T/ET% ratios and of ET. The mean bias and root-mean-square error (RMSE) of E/ET% were 1% and 2%, respectively, and the mean bias and RMSE of T/ET% were −1% and 2%, respectively. In addition, the model exhibited relatively reliable estimates in the latent heat flux, with mean bias and RMSE values of 31 and 61 W·m−2, respectively, compared with the measurements from the EC system. These results demonstrated that a robust soil and vegetation component temperature calculation was crucial for estimating E, T, and ET. Moreover, the separate validation of E/ET% and T/ET% provides a good prospect for TSEB model improvements.

Our results demonstrated that the TSEB model using soil and canopy component radiometric temperatures, which were obtained from a high-precision thermal infrared camera, can be applied in a strongly advection-irrigated agricultural area. Notably, the results illustrated that the latent fluxes of the soil and vegetation components were successfully separated with reasonable accuracy, as assessed using ground-based measurements. The estimated E/ET% and E/ET% values agreed well with the values observed using the stable oxygen and hydrogen isotopes technique during the early, middle, and late growing seasons. In addition, the TSEB model produced reliable estimations of Rn, H, and LE; the mean biases of Rn, H, and LE were −18, 5, and 31 W ·m−2, respectively, and the RMSEs of Rn, H, and LE were 29, 19, and 61 W · m−2, respectively. This finding suggests that given accurate soil and vegetation component temperatures, E and T can be accurately separated from ET using the TSEB model.

background: Upscaling of eco-hydrological processes on a heterogeneous surface is a grand challenge. Progress in this field is hindered by the poor availability of multiscale observations. HiWATER is an experiment designed to address this challenge through instrumentation on hierarchically nested scales to obtain multiscale and multidisciplinary data.
challenges: Progress in this field is hindered by the poor availability of multiscale observations.
methods: Several intensive observation periods (IOPs) and continuous hydrometeorological observations were carried out during HiWATER. Only data collected during the IOP in 2012 are presented in this paper. Instruments for the oasis-desert system were arranged in hierarchically nested scales to capture multi-scale eco-hydrological processes. We established a sparse network to investigate the oasis-desert interaction. One superstation was constructed within the oasis, and four EC towers and four two-layer automatic meteorological stations (AMSs) were installed in different landscapes surrounding the oasis, including sandy desert, desert pavement, desert steppe, and wetland. Intensive observations were implemented at the irrigation district scale. A total of 12 airborne remote sensing missions were conducted to cover the FEA using LiDAR, an imaging spectrometer, a multi-angle thermal imager, and an L-band microwave radiometer.
dataset: We introduce a multiscale dataset obtained from Heihe Watershed Allied Telemetry Experimental Research (HiWATER) in an oasis-desert area in 2012. The HiWATER observation system consists of a flux observation matrix of eddy covariance towers, large aperture scintillometers, and automatic meteorological stations; an eco-hydrological sensor network of soil moisture and leaf area index; hyper-resolution airborne remote sensing using LiDAR, imaging spectrometer, multi-angle thermal imager, and L-band microwave radiometer; and synchronical ground measurements of vegetation dynamics and photosynthesis processes. All observational data were carefully quality controlled throughout sensor calibration, data collection, data processing, and datasets generation. The data are freely available at figshare and the Cold and Arid Regions Science Data Centre.

Example.Answer: An example of a challenge faced in collecting multi-scale observational data for eco-hydrological processes is the poor availability of multiscale observations, which hinders progress in upscaling eco-hydrological processes on heterogeneous surfaces. This challenge was addressed in the HiWATER experiment by using instrumentation on hierarchically nested scales.

Example.Answer: An example of a dataset that includes both remote sensing and ground-based measurements is the one obtained from the HiWATER experiment. This dataset includes hyper-resolution airborne remote sensing using LiDAR, an imaging spectrometer, a multi-angle thermal imager, and an L-band microwave radiometer, along with synchronical ground measurements of vegetation dynamics and photosynthesis processes.

Definition.Question: What is a flux observation matrix in the context of eco-hydrological data collection?
Definition.Answer: A flux observation matrix is a component of a multiscale dataset that includes eddy covariance towers, large aperture scintillometers, and automatic meteorological stations. It is designed to capture multi-scale eco-hydrological processes by providing detailed measurements of turbulent fluxes and other meteorological parameters.

Definition.Question: What does the 'eddy covariance (EC) system' refer to in the measurement of evapotranspiration?
Definition.Answer: The eddy covariance (EC) system is a method used to measure turbulent fluxes of heat, water vapor, and carbon dioxide between the land surface and the atmosphere. It involves high-frequency sampling of wind speed and scalar quantities to determine fluxes, which are essential for accurately estimating evapotranspiration (ET) and its components in various environments.

Definition.Question: What are 'multiscale observations' in the context of eco-hydrological research?
Definition.Answer: Multiscale observations refer to data collected at various spatial and temporal scales to capture the complex interactions and processes occurring in eco-hydrological systems. They involve a variety of instruments and methodologies, such as remote sensing and ground-based measurements, to provide comprehensive insights into the dynamics of heterogeneous landscapes.

Comparison.Question: What are the differences in observational data quality control between the flux observation matrix and hyper-resolution airborne remote sensing in the HiWATER research?
Comparison.Answer: The flux observation matrix involves the use of eddy covariance towers and automatic meteorological stations with data quality control focused on sensor calibration and data collection. Hyper-resolution airborne remote sensing, on the other hand, uses instruments like LiDAR and imaging spectrometers, with quality control extending to data processing and dataset generation. Both approaches require careful calibration, but they differ in the types of sensors and the scale of data they handle.

Interpretation.Question: How can the integration of multiscale observation techniques provide a more comprehensive understanding of eco-hydrological processes in heterogeneous landscapes?
Interpretation.Answer: The integration of multiscale observation techniques, such as those used in the Heihe Watershed Allied Telemetry Experimental Research (HiWATER), allows for the collection of diverse data types across different spatial and temporal scales. This includes the use of eddy covariance towers, large aperture scintillometers, automatic meteorological stations, and remote sensing technologies like LiDAR and thermal imagers. By capturing data from nested scales and multiple perspectives, researchers can better understand the interactions between various eco-hydrological processes in complex landscapes like oasis-desert systems.

Interpretation.Question: What are the potential challenges in ensuring the accuracy and reliability of data collected using eddy covariance systems in strongly advective environments?
Interpretation.Answer: In strongly advective environments, the accuracy and reliability of data from eddy covariance systems can be affected by incomplete energy balance closure, errors in surface-air temperature difference estimations, and uncertainties in determining soil and vegetation component temperatures. These challenges are compounded by the complexity of measuring turbulent fluxes accurately, especially when the mean heat flux (H) is small. Image classification errors, atmospheric upwelling radiation, and transmittance issues can also contribute to inaccuracies in component temperature estimation.

Interpretation.Question: How can the use of a high-resolution thermal camera and stable isotope techniques refine the estimation of evapotranspiration components in agricultural regions?
Interpretation.Answer: The use of a high-resolution thermal camera allows for precise measurement of soil and canopy component temperatures, which are critical inputs for the two-source energy balance (TSEB) model. When combined with stable oxygen and hydrogen isotope techniques, these measurements enable a more accurate separation of evaporation (E) and transpiration (T) components of evapotranspiration (ET). By validating these estimates against eddy covariance system measurements, researchers can enhance the reliability of ET assessments, especially in regions with complex advective conditions like irrigated agricultural areas.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to the poor availability of multiscale observations in eco-hydrological research?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Progress in the field of upscaling eco-hydrological processes on a heterogeneous surface is hindered by the poor availability of multiscale observations. This is due to the complexity of capturing multi-scale eco-hydrological processes, which requires hierarchically nested instrumentation and a sparse network to investigate interactions in diverse landscapes such as oasis-desert systems.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why is it challenging to accurately estimate evapotranspiration using one-source models in heterogeneous landscape conditions?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: One-source evapotranspiration estimation models face challenges in accurately estimating surface evapotranspiration in heterogeneous landscapes because these models combine soil and vegetation components into a single source. In real landscape conditions, the surface is heterogeneous and contains a mixture of soil and vegetation with different temperatures and resistance to energy exchange, which one-source models cannot accurately account for.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What are the causes of errors in estimating soil and canopy component temperatures in strongly advective irrigated agricultural areas?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Errors in estimating soil and canopy component temperatures in strongly advective irrigated agricultural areas are primarily caused by image classification errors, which vary with vegetation abundance. These errors lead to incorrect classification of soil and vegetation pixels, resulting in overestimation of canopy temperature. Additionally, ignoring atmospheric upwelling radiation and transmittance and uncertainties in estimating incoming short- and long-wave radiation transmittances through the canopy can contribute to errors in estimating temperatures.

Causal Consequence.Question: What potential challenges arise from the hierarchical multi-scale observation system in eco-hydrological research?
Causal Consequence.Answer: The hierarchical multi-scale observation system aims to capture multi-scale eco-hydrological processes, but it faces challenges such as the poor availability of multiscale observations and the complexity of managing a network that includes eddy covariance towers, automatic meteorological stations, and remote sensing instruments. These challenges can hinder progress in understanding and modeling eco-hydrological processes on heterogeneous surfaces.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to establish a multiscale observation experiment in eco-hydrological studies on heterogeneous land surfaces?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The goal is to address the challenge of poor availability of multiscale observations needed to upscale eco-hydrological processes. This is achieved through instrumentation on hierarchically nested scales to obtain multiscale and multidisciplinary data, as demonstrated by the HiWATER experiment.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why are high-resolution thermal cameras used in data collection for estimating soil and canopy component temperatures?
Goal Orientation.Answer: High-resolution thermal cameras are utilized to provide precise inputs for the TSEB model, which helps in better estimating evaporation, transpiration, and evapotranspiration by accurately capturing soil and canopy component temperatures, crucial for reliable model performance in strongly advective environments.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How are multiscale observations structured to capture eco-hydrological processes in heterogeneous landscapes during the HiWATER experiment?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Instruments are arranged in hierarchically nested scales to capture multiscale eco-hydrological processes. This includes a sparse network for oasis-desert interaction investigation, a superstation within the oasis, and multiple EC towers and automatic meteorological stations in surrounding landscapes like sandy desert, desert pavement, desert steppe, and wetland. Intensive observations are carried out at the irrigation district scale, with additional remote sensing missions using LiDAR, an imaging spectrometer, a multi-angle thermal imager, and an L-band microwave radiometer.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What are the steps involved in processing ground-based thermal infrared camera data to separate soil and canopy temperatures for evapotranspiration estimation?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The visible and NIR images are classified into soil and canopy pixels using the maximum-likelihood method. Soil and canopy directional brightness temperatures are extracted from thermal images. These temperatures are converted to radiation temperatures using incoming long-wave radiation and soil and canopy emissivities. Finally, simulated radiometric temperatures are validated against surface radiometric temperatures calculated from four-component radiometer observations.

Enablement.Question: How do advancements in remote sensing technologies facilitate the collection of multiscale eco-hydrological data in oasis-desert areas?
Enablement.Answer: The advancements in remote sensing technologies such as LiDAR, imaging spectrometers, multi-angle thermal imagers, and L-band microwave radiometers facilitate the collection of multiscale eco-hydrological data by enabling airborne remote sensing missions that capture detailed information over large areas.

Enablement.Question: What strategies are employed to ensure the quality control of observational data collected in highly heterogeneous landscapes?
Enablement.Answer: Quality control strategies include sensor calibration, data collection protocols, data processing, and dataset generation, ensuring that all observational data are meticulously checked for accuracy, especially in heterogeneous landscapes like the oasis-desert areas involved in the HiWATER project.

Expectation.Question: Why might multiscale observations be difficult to obtain in heterogeneous landscapes for eco-hydrological studies?
Expectation.Answer: Progress in this field is hindered by the poor availability of multiscale observations. HiWATER is an experiment designed to address this challenge through instrumentation on hierarchically nested scales to obtain multiscale and multidisciplinary data.

Expectation.Question: Why is the TSEB model's performance affected by uncertainties in surface-air temperature differences, especially in strongly advective environments?
Expectation.Answer: The previous sensitivity studies found that the TSEB model performance is mainly affected by the uncertainty in surface–air temperature difference. Sometimes, this difference is dominant due to the errors in determining the surface soil and vegetation component temperatures from the surface composite radiometric temperature. This often leads to the most crucial effect on the TSEB model performance.

Judgmental.Question: How effective do you consider the use of two-source energy balance (TSEB) models in estimating evapotranspiration over heterogeneous landscapes, given the challenges in accurate temperature separation?
Judgmental.Answer: The TSEB model is generally effective for estimating evapotranspiration, especially when soil and vegetation component temperatures are accurately measured. However, its effectiveness can be limited by errors in composite temperature separation, particularly in arid regions or when classification errors occur due to varying vegetation abundance.

Assertion.Question: I don't understand why the data collection methods in eco-hydrology can't capture multiscale observations effectively.
Assertion.Answer: The challenges in capturing multiscale observations in eco-hydrology arise from the poor availability of multiscale data. HiWATER addresses this challenge by using a hierarchically nested scale approach with various instruments, such as eddy covariance towers and automatic meteorological stations, to obtain multiscale and multidisciplinary data.

Assertion.Question: I'm unsure about how multiscale datasets are generated and quality controlled in the context of the HiWATER experiment.
Assertion.Answer: Multiscale datasets in the HiWATER experiment are generated through a combination of ground-based measurements, such as eddy covariance towers, and airborne remote sensing technologies like LiDAR and imaging spectrometers. The data undergo rigorous quality control, including sensor calibration and data processing, to ensure reliability, and are made available through platforms like figshare and the Cold and Arid Regions Science Data Centre.

Request/Directive.Question: Please analyze the methodologies used for partitioning evapotranspiration into soil evaporation and plant transpiration, and discuss their effectiveness in heterogeneous terrains.
Request/Directive.Answer: Methodologies for partitioning evapotranspiration (ET) into evaporation (E) and transpiration (T) involve using the two-source energy balance (TSEB) model combined with field observations. Ground-based data, such as soil and canopy component temperatures, are used alongside thermal infrared images to estimate and validate E and T. The TSEB model, when applied in strongly advective irrigated agricultural areas, demonstrates reliable estimates of E/ET% and T/ET% ratios, though challenges like composite temperature separation in arid regions persist.

Request/Directive.Question: Please suggest potential strategies for enhancing the multiscale observational capacity in eco-hydrological studies within oasis-desert systems.
Request/Directive.Answer: Enhancing multiscale observational capacity in eco-hydrological studies can be achieved through hierarchical nesting of observational instruments, such as eddy covariance towers, large aperture scintillometers, and automatic meteorological stations. Incorporating hyper-resolution airborne remote sensing tools like LiDAR, imaging spectrometers, and multi-angle thermal imagers, alongside ground measurements of vegetation dynamics and photosynthesis, can capture diverse eco-hydrological processes. These methods provide comprehensive datasets for understanding interactions across oasis-desert systems.
